bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Estela Agramonte Rodriguez Leon, August 21, 1950

div1.p: Hench discusses conflicting evidence concerning Agramonte's presence in Cuba at the time of Lazear's death, and offers his own opinion.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Estela Agramonte Rodriguez Leon, August 21, 1950
div1.opener:
August 21, 1950
Senora Estela Agramonte de Rodriguez Leon
K Street No. 254
Vedado, Havana
Cuba
My dear Senora Rodriguez Leon:
div1.p:
Saturday I notified you by cable that I had been away and that I
was assembling your father's data. Yesterday I sent you air mail a key to
the tin box in which today I have air mailed, by registered post, your father's
data. All of the material is returned. Herewith I enclose an extra key in
case the one should have been lost. Just keep the tin box, it may be of use
to you.

I am delighted to know that the present government is finally in-
terested in doing something with respect to the work of your father and the
other members of the U. S. Army Board and of course Finlay. If the lectures
are published, I would certainly appreciate having at least one copy. If there
is a price for the lectures, please let me know. Someone certainly ought to
collect them.

I appreciate very greatly indeed your permission to borrow those
papers of your father's and am sure that they will arrive safely. We put on
the outside a sticker as follows: “Cuban Postmaster and Customs Officials:
This is a tin box containing nothing but old letters of considerable personal
value but of no commercial value whatever.” I hope that by this note the box
will not be held up in customs but delivered to your home, and our local post
office thought that that would be the case.

Regarding your postscript, I have a fairly complete record of your
father's comings and goings, orders and appointments that I collected from
data chiefly in the National Archives Building in Washington. There is no
question but that he was absent from Havana from about September 23, certainly
from September 24, to October 12, 1900. Your own papers which I am returning
also established the fact and the reason for his absence and the National Archives
contains his Personal Report written in his own handwriting confirming this
“leave of absence” which was later considered not as a formal leave but as a
special erand for reasons which your papers show.

There is confirmatory evidence regarding this in an article by Hemmeter,
written in English and published in a Dutch historical magazine, Janus 1908, are
printed a number of letters from Carroll to his wife. In one letter dated
September 23, 1900, Carroll wrote to his wife “Agramonte left for New York yesterday
with his wife.” Your father had originally had a 15 day leave-of-absence granted
by Special Order 164, Headquarters Division of Cuba, September 21. The U. S,
Army transport Sedgewick, left Havana September_24 and returned October 12.
General Truby who was at Lazear's funeral has been puzzled through the years
Senora Estela Agramonte de Rodriguez Leon
- 2 -
August 21, 1950
to know why your father was not at Lazear's funeral. Indeed, no member
of the Board was at Lazear's funeral and he commented upon this in his book
and there is also a very brief note about your father's absence, saying that
he was on leave. The return trip of the Sedgewick took 18 days and it is
General Truby's assumption, which seems to be born out by your father's
Personal Report, that he took the Sedgewick as he left on the day that the
boat left Havana and returned on the day that the boat returned to Havana
but since he only had 15 days leave the additional three days was taken care
of by giving him a three-day extension of leave as per Special Order 182,
Headquarters Division of Cuba, October 16, 1900.

In view of your father's own records, the above can hardly be dis-
puted. The only two places where your father permitted another inference were
as follows. In a letter to Mrs. Mabel Lazear dated July 15, 1930, on your
father's stationery, he wrote a lovely letter of condolence and reminisced
about his contacts with Doctor Lazear. One sentence reads “Every moment of
our contact at Camp Columbia is still vivid in my mind until the moment of
his (Lazear's) passing away at the hospital, which day I shall never forget as
long as I live.” One must consider that your father was merely using a figure
of speech. Your father knew that Lazear was sick but may or may not have
realized when he last saw him, how very ill Lazear was. I doubt very much if
your father knew of Lazear's death until some time after he landed in New
York. Also in this same vein, one must interpret your father's remarks on
page 562 of the Military Surgeon, November 1930, paragraph 3, which constitutes
the 6th page of your father's article in the Military Surgeon, “One contribution
by Army Medical Officers to Science”, in which your father describes the worry
of those in care of Lazear. One sentence reads “On September 26 we buried him.”
Again that is a figure of speech. Obviously when he learned later of Lazear's
death, undoubtedly he regretted his absence and as he pondered over the un-
fortunate illness and death of Lazear he doubtless grieved as if he had been
there and later expressed his thoughts along those lines. In other words, I
think your father meant that he was there in spirit even though he did not
so state.

All of this however is not particularly important but since you
raised the question. I am giving you the information. I have all of Reed's
letters to his widow and of course Reed was in Washington at the time and knew
even less about Lazear's illness than did your father.

In a few days, if I can clear up a very crowded desk, I will send
you a two or three page synopsis of your father's orders, goings and comings,
and activities between April 18, 1898 when he wrote to General Sternberg
offering his services and June 15, 1903 when his second Army contract was ended.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
